results.title: C'est l'aviron
results.creator_credit: Norman McLaren and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chants populaires”.
A short animated version of a French folk song. McLaren used gouache drawings which he superimposed against a scenic background to give the impression of a boat travelling along a lake and river which he acheived by zooming during the photographic process.

results.title: La-haut sur ces montagnes. C'est l'aviron.
results.creator_credit: Norman McLaren, Jean Palardy and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chants populaires”.
Animated interpretation of two French folk songs. Featuring Madeleine Lachance and the Quatuor Alouette. ‘La-haut sur ces montagnes’ (2.59 mins) is set on the island of Orleans near Quebec, where traditional dances and folksongs are kept alive by the peasant community. In ‘C’est l’aviron’ (3.15 mins) McLaren used gouache drawings which he superimposed against a scenic background to give the impression of a boat travelling along a lake and river which he acheived by zooming during the photographic process.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Norman McLaren, Jean Palardy and National Film Board of Canada
results.description:
Episode of Series “Chants populaires”.
Animated interpretation of two French folk songs. Featuring Madeleine Lachance and the Quatuor Alouette. ‘La-haut sur ces montagnes’ (2.59 mins) is set on the island of Orleans near Quebec, where traditional dances and folksongs are kept alive by the peasant community. In ‘C’est l’aviron’ (3.15 mins) McLaren used gouache drawings which he superimposed against a scenic background to give the impression of a boat travelling along a lake and river which he acheived by zooming during the photographic process.
description_for_label:

In ‘C’est l’aviron’ (3.15 mins) McLaren used gouache drawings which he superimposed against a scenic background to give the impression of a boat travelling along a lake and river which he acheived by zooming during the photographic process.

Animated interpretation of the French folk song “La-haut sur ces Montagnes” set on the island of Orleans near Quebec, where traditional dances and songs are kept alive by the peasant community. Featuring Madeleine Lachance and the Quatuor Alouette.

results.title: Isolated but not Alone
results.brief_description: A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Journeys with Breast Cancer” Created in association with Breast Cancer Network Australia.I love living in the bush, I especially love rearing my kids in a rural area. It’s something about the sense of freedom, space and community. But distance can be hard when you have a serious illness.
results.description: A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Journeys with Breast Cancer” Created in association with Breast Cancer Network Australia.I love living in the bush, I especially love rearing my kids in a rural area. It’s something about the sense of freedom, space and community. But distance can be hard when you have a serious illness.

results.title: Living not dying
results.brief_description: A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Journeys with Breast Cancer” Created in association with Breast Cancer Network Australia. “For the past six years, I have been living with, not dying from, advanced breast cancer. My original diagnosis was in 1996, when I was 40 years old.”
results.description: A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Journeys with Breast Cancer” Created in association with Breast Cancer Network Australia. “For the past six years, I have been living with, not dying from, advanced breast cancer. My original diagnosis was in 1996, when I was 40 years old.”

results.title: Wild at Heart
results.brief_description: A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Journeys with Breast Cancer” Created in association with Breast Cancer Network Australia. “They say tragedy comes in threes, my mum’s cancer, my brother’s accident and now me.”
